definition: Behavior where a party reveals compliance evidence only when advantageous, hiding problems elsewhere.

positive_examples: Updates are provided only on the happiest metrics.
Negative findings are delayed until after renewals.
One party shares evidence only under NDA while demanding openness from us.
Compliance memos cherry-pick months with good scores.
They brief leadership verbally but refuse written reports.
Audit trails exist for some clauses but not others.
Requests for raw data are ignored until public pressure mounts.
Surprise disclosures occur during unrelated meetings.
Information is split among channels to prevent full view.
Risk memos stay internal until leaked.
They cite privacy to avoid sharing while still marketing success.
Probe downtime is disclosed only after we discover it.
Claims of confidentiality spike when metrics decline.
Shared evidence contradicts what they tell regulators.
negative_examples: Both parties receive identical evidence packets.
Redacted reports include justification and timelines.
Trend charts include all months, not just select ones.
Formal reports follow after verbal briefings.
Raw data requests are fulfilled quickly.
Issues are disclosed in governance forums, not backchannels.
Information is centralized to maintain shared context.
Risk memos are published to both sides simultaneously.
Privacy concerns are addressed with solution options.
Probe downtime notifications go out immediately.
Confidential segments include rationale and expiry.
Evidence shared with regulators matches what we see.
training_hints.disambiguation: Behavior where a party reveals compliance evidence only when advantageous, hiding problems elsewhere.
